data.title: Knife (Kard) with Battling Elephants, Rhinoceros and Lions on the sheath
data.medium_display: Watered steel, ivory, and pierced and chased gold, wood and velvet
data.credit_line: James W. and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection. Gift of Marilynn Alsdorf
data.publication_history: Pratapaditya Pal with contributions by Stephen Little, A Collecting Odyssey: Indian, Himalayan, and Southeast Asian Art from the James and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago in association with Thames and Hudson, 1997), 243 (ill.), 347, cat. 332.
data.exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, A Collecting Odyssey: Indian, Himalayan, and Southeast Asian Art from the James and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection, Aug. 2–Oct. 26, 1997, cat. 332.
data.provenance_text: With Kapoor Galleries, New York, by May 14, 1987 [this and the following according to receipt from Kapoor Galleries, May 14, 1987; copy in curatorial object file]; sold to James W. Alsdorf (1913–1990) and Marilynn B. Alsdorf (1925–2019), Winnetka and Chicago IL, by May 14, 1987; by descent to Marilynn B. Alsdorf, Chicago, 1990 [on long-term loan at the Art Institute of Chicago, Sept. 17, 1997; publicly promised as a gift to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1997; offered as a promised gift to the Art Institute, 2002]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2022.

data.title: Lotus
data.artist_display:
Design attributed to May Morris (English, 1862–1938)
Produced by Morris & Co., London (English, 1875–1940)
Embroidered by the Decorative Arts Society, Chicago (American, founded 1877)
data.medium_display: Silk, warp-float faced twill weave; embroidered in satin and stem stitches
data.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. John J. Glessner
data.exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Agnes Allerton Gallery, A Selection of Fabrics from the 1880s–1940s from the Permanent Collection, Nov. 13, 1982–Feb. 15, 1983. Art Institute of Chicago, Morris and Company: The Business of Beauty, Dec. 18, 2021–June 13, 2022, no cat.
data.provenance_text: Frances Glessner (Mrs. John J. Glessner, born Sarah Frances Macbeth, 1848-1932), and John J. Glessner, Chicago,Ill., from around 1888 [according to correspondence from William Tyre dated May 18, 2011 in curatorial file and Mrs. Glessner’s personal dairy this was one of four 'curtains' received by her on Nov. 17, 1888; they were installed in east doors of the east doors of the parlor at Glessner House, Prairie Street, Chicago; photographed c. 1890 in situ; gift recorded in Day Book 8, p. 150]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1918.
